title.narrative: OHCHR Asia-Pacific promote and protect human rights
OHCHR Strengthening cap. of reg. actors to protect human rights

description.narrative:
Insatsen syftar till att bidra till genomförandet av Sveriges regionala strategi för utvecklinssamarbetet i Asien och Oceanien genom att stärka OHCHR:s regionala kontor i Asien och Stilla havet. Syftet är att bidra till att stärka regionala aktörers kapacitet att främja mänskliga rättigheter, ansvarutkrävande, demokratiskt utrymme och jämställdhet i Asien och Oceanien.
Insatsen innebär ett finansiellt regionalt programstöd till FN:s Högkommissiaries regionala kontor i Bangkok och Suva. Insatsen avser att bidra till genomförandet av OHCHR's regionala program för Asien och Stilla havet och följer OHCHR strategiska plan och deras regionala program för Asien och Oceanien.
Projektet syftar framför allt till att möjligöra att OHCHR kan stärka bemanning och kapaciteten av det regionala kontoret i Bangkok genom inrättandet av 7 nya tjänster med spjutspetskomptens inom områden som miljö/klimat, ekonomiska sociala och kulturella rättigheter och migration, inklusive människohandel och migration.
I OHCHR:s projektunderlag har de föreslagit att Sverige ska bidra till följande områden:
- Stärk kapacitet hos regionala aktörer att integrera mänskliga rättigheter i arbete med migration, människohandel och modernt slaveri - Stärkt kapacitet hos regionala aktörer att främja mänskliga rättigheter i relation till klimatförändringar, miljö samt ekonomiska, sociala och kulturella rättigheter - Stärkt kapacitet hos regionala aktörer att främja och skydda det demokratiska utrymmet - Stärkta regionala mekanismer för att främja och skydda mänskliga rättigheter - Ökad integrering av mänskliga rättigheter inom FN-systemet, inklusive FN:s utvecklingsgrupp med ansvar för Asien och Stilla havet.

Program support to OHCHR regional Office. The contribution aims to strengthen the capacity of regional actors to promote human rights, accountability, democratic space and gender in Asia and the Pacific.

The intervention seeks to improve the capacity of regional and national actors to respect, protect and implement human rights in the Asia-Pacific region. The direct target groups are states in their capacity as duty-bearers and responsible for their human rights obligations and civil society organisations, academia and other actors working to strenghen the capacity of rights holders to claim their rights. OHCHR seek to increase the knowledge about international standards and state obligations for human rights and how these translate into the human rights challenges faced in the Asia-Pacific region.

participating-org.narrative: OHCHR/Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights
OHCHR/Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights

tag.narrative: 16.10 - 0 Säkerställa allmän tillgång till information och skydda grundläggande friheter, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning och internationella avtal.
16.10 - Ensure public access to information and protect fundamental freedoms, in accordance with national legislation and international agreements.
16.3 - Främja rättssäkerheten på nationell och internationell nivå samt säkerställa lika tillgång till rättvisa för alla.
16.3 - Promote the rule of law at the national and international levels and ensure equal access to justice for all.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.

Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative:
In Asia and the Pacific, COVID-19 has reinforced the weaknesses that made population vulnerable to the pandemic – rising inequalities, unfulfilled economic, social and cultural rights, environmental degradation and climate change, discrimination, gender-based violence, social cohesion, lack of participation and a shrinking civic space. The project ‘Strengthening capacity of regional actors to promote human rights, accountability, democratic space and gender in the Asia-Pacific region (2018-2022)’ is proven even more relevant under the Covid context. However some of activities have been delayed due to the travel restriction. Conferences and trainings have been moved to an online format instead in 2020.
In 2020, the highlights of activities include: -conducting regular monitoring and advocacy on the impact of COVID-19 on migrants; continuing the collaboration with the UN Regional Migration Network; and supporting States and partners to conduct the first regional review of the Global Compact for Migration. - holding webinars to address the impact of climate change on human rights, including through the nexus with business and human rights. The protection of environmental HRDs and the implementation of the MOU with UNEP will continue to be a priority. - A regional consultation with HRDs in advance of a public report planned in 2021, a series of webinars for women journalists and media workers, in close collaboration with UN Women, and the launch of an interactive map on communications by the Special Procedures in relation to civic space. - Much of the work on human rights mainstreaming has been significantly impacted and refocused around COVID-19. For example, Common Country Analysis (CCAs) that will be submitted this year will be slim versions, due to the refocusing of priorities on the socio-economic response to the pandemic. - The OHCHRSouth-East Asia Regional office (SEARO) is now, in addition to the UN human rights network, co-chairing the UN Issue Based Coalition (IBC) on Human Rights, Gender Equality and Women’s Empowerment.
Examples of activities and results from 2019:
Result 1: Strengthened capacity of regional actors to address human rights issues related migration, trafficking and modern slavery - The session chaired by the OHCHR Senior Migration Advisor at the UN Business and Human Rights Forum in Geneva resulted in an invitation to the OHCHRSouth-East Asia Regional office (SEARO) to speak on issues of hate speech, migration and business to an audience of hundreds of advertising industry and private companies at a key global advertising industry conference in 2020. - The multi-stakeholder meeting ‘Reshaping narratives on migration in Asia and the Pacific’ resulted in outreach to over 40 CSOs and entities who work with migrants and minority communities at local levels, many of whom had not previously engaged with SEARO. - SEARO worked closely with UN agencies to draft the Terms of Reference for the UN Regional Network on Migration for Asia and the Pacific and joined the Executive Committee upon the formation of the Network in November 2019. Result 2: Strengthened capacity of regional actors to promote human rights arising in the context of climate change, including economic, social and cultural rights and environmental rights - The consultation with business and private sector actors on Addressing Environmental Harms – The Business and Human Rights Connection, jointly organised with SEARO and UNEP , brought business actors together to enhance their understanding of the relationship between human rights and the environment, and the responsibilities of businesses. - The session on the Pacific organised by OHCHR Regional Office for the Pacific Region (ROP) at the UN Business and Human Rights Forum in Geneva introduced governments, civil society, academics, private businesses, NHRIs and other actors to the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights. The session’s aim was to kick start the development of a Pacific National Action Plan on Business and Human Rights in one Pacific nation, with a specific focus on green and blue economies, which can then be replicated by other Small Island Development States. - The MOU with UNEP provided an important platform to further strengthen SEARO’s partnership with a focus on EHRDs. - During the Asian CSOs Regional Consultation on the rights of Indigenous Peoples and the UN Special Rapporteur on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples, emphasis was placed on the impact of climate change on the enjoyment of economic, social and cultural rights and the critical role played by indigenous peoples in protecting the environment, including through traditional knowledge. The consultation fed into the report of the UN Special Rapporteur on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples to the Human Rights Council in 2020.
Result 3: Strengthened capacity of regional actors to promote and protect democratic space The SEARO and UNEP joint Regional Workshop on Environmental Reporting for journalists and media workers held in October allowed the exchange of experiences and the identification of issues of concern regarding environmental reporting in South-East Asia. The workshop also provided journalists and EHRDs to engage with regional actors, such as Internews Earth Journalism Network. The regional meeting on Technology and human rights: opportunities and challenges in South-East Asia proved to be an important innovative platform, enabling SEARO to facilitate a discussion amongst relevant CSOs and tech partners at the regional level. As a result of SEARO’s support, the ICJ provided a legal overview of the national legal frameworks in South-East Asia and their multiple restrictions on freedom of expression which provided an important baseline for their further advocacy efforts. Result 4: Strengthened regional mechanisms to promote and protect human rights Following the ICJ’s ASEAN lawyer’s meeting, participants agreed to develop regional guidelines on freedom of association of workers in ASEAN and to form a Working Group that would be tasked to develop these guidelines. The Working Group is composed of trade union representatives at the national level, lawyers, and other civil society representatives. The ICJ conducted initial working group consultations, for which they translated documents related to the draft Guidelines on Freedom of Association in South-East Asia into local languages (Bahasa Indonesia, Burmese, Khmer and Thai).
Result 5: Human rights mainstreaming within the UN system, including the UN Development Group for the Asia Pacific - Together with UNFPA, UN Women and UNEP, SEARO initiated the development of a regional version of the global UN common learning package on a HRBA to be used for trainings in the Asia-Pacific which builds upon the experience in the Asia Pacific region. - SEARO increased its engagement with national and regional processes on the implementation of the 2030 Agenda. This included participation in the DESA-ESCAP led workshop held in March, for countries in the Asia-Pacific presenting reports under the Voluntary National Review (VNRs) in 2019. During the APFSD, SEARO also co-organized two side-events entitled ‘Empowering the most marginalized and ensuring inclusiveness and equality: Realizing the SDGs through Human Rights’ and ‘Ensuring women’s inclusiveness and equality in land rights and management of natural resources: The role of Women Human Rights Defenders’. SEARO also supported the “People’s Forum” for civil society held in preparation for the APFSD.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
